Package com.teracloud.streams.dps

Interface Store

All Superinterfaces:
Iterable<KeyValuePair>
public interface Store extends Iterable<KeyValuePair>
Represents a user created distributed store. Methods are available for adding and removing elements from the store. 

StoreFactory sf = DistributedStores.getStoreFactory();
Store store = null;
try {
   //specify the SPL types for the keys and values in the store
   String keyType = "rstring";
   String valueType = "int32";
   store = sf.createOrGetStore("Java Test Store1", keyType, valueType);
} catch (StoreFactoryException sfe) {
 throw sfe;
  //or use      sfe.getErrorCode() and  sfe.getErrorMessage()) for more info
}


//once ready to access the store,
//get a lock for the store, may have previously been created
LockFactory lf = DistributedLocks.getLockFactory(); 
Lock myLock = lf.createOrGetLock("Lock_For_Test_Store1");

// Acquire the lock
try {
        myLock.acquireLock();
} catch (LockException le) {
    throw le;
}

//perform store operations
store.put("IBM", 39);
store.put("Lenovo", 50);
//release the lock  when finished
myLock.releaseLock();
Iterating over the elements in the store is possible using the iterator method, or in a simple "foreach" statement as follows: 
           
for (KeyValuePair kv: store) {
  System.out.println("'" + kv.getKey() + "' => '" + kv.getValue() + "'");
}

  • Method Details

    • getId

      long getId()

    • put

      <T1, T2> boolean put(T1 key, T2 value) throws StoreException
      Insert a key/value pair into the store. The types of your key and value must be the same ones that were provided at the time of creating the store. If you don't follow that rule, your store operations will produce undesired results. The types of key and value must be the same as the types specified when the store was created. This method does not perform any internal safety checks. 
       
long tickerId = 46267353;
String tickerSymbol = "IBM";

try {
   store.put(tickerSymbol, tickerId);
} catch (StoreException se) {
   throw se;
}
      Type Parameters:
      T1 - key to store with the value
      T2 - value associated with the key
      Returns:
      true on success, false otherwise
      Throws:
      StoreException - on failure or error.

    • putSafe

      <T1, T2> boolean putSafe(T1 key, T2 value) throws StoreException
      Same function as put, but slower due to overhead arising from internal safety checks.
      Type Parameters:
      T1 - key to store with the value
      T2 - value associated with the key
      Returns:
      true on success, false otherwise
      Throws:
      StoreException - on failure or error.

    • get

      <T1> Object get(T1 key) throws StoreException
      Get the value associated with the given key. This method performs faster than getSafe because it does not do any internal safety checks.
      Type Parameters:
      T1 - key to look up
      Returns:
      the saved value associated with the key
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs

    • getSafe

      <T1> Object getSafe(T1 key) throws StoreException
      Similar to get but with higher overhead arising from internal safety checks.
      Type Parameters:
      T1 - the key to look up
      Returns:
      the saved value associated with the key
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs

    • remove

      <T1> boolean remove(T1 key) throws StoreException
      Removes the given key from the store.
      Type Parameters:
      T1 - key to remove
      Returns:
      true if the key was successfully removed
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs.

    • has

      <T1> boolean has(T1 key) throws StoreException
      Check if the store contains a value for the given key
      Type Parameters:
      T1 - the key to look up
      Returns:
      whether or not if the store has a value for the key
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs.

    • clear

      void clear() throws StoreException
      Deletes all the key-value pairs in this store.
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs.

    • size

      long size() throws StoreException
      Returns:
      the total number of K/V pairs stored in this store
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs clearing the store.

    • serialize

      ByteBuffer serialize() throws StoreException
      Serialize the contents of this store into a ByteBuffer. The resulting ByteBuffer can then be used to recreate all the K/V pairs into another store. This is a useful technique for copying an entire store into a different store. See deserialize() for a complete example
      Returns:
      a ByteBuffer containing the serialized contents of the store.
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs during serialization

    • deserialize

      void deserialize(ByteBuffer data) throws StoreException
      Deserializes a ByteBuffer containing one or more serialized key-value pairs into this store, thereby populating it with those pairs.
      Parameters:
      data - ByteBuffer containing the serialized data
      Throws:
      StoreException - if an error occurs. 
      
//create a store 
Store topBrandsStore = sf.createOrGetStore("ABC", "int32", "ustring");
// Add few data items.
topBrandsStore.put(3, "Thinkpad");
topBrandsStore.put(4, "Watson");
// Serialize this entire store now.
ByteBuffer serializedStore = null;

try {
   serializedStore = topBrandsStore.serialize();
} catch (StoreException se) {
   System.out.println("Problem in serializing the store ");
      throw se;
}

// Deserialize the byte buffer containing the serialized store contents and populate a brand new store.
// Remove the top brands store to demonstrate that deserialization is independent of the original store
sf.removeStore(topBrandsStore);
topBrandsStore = null;
//create a new store
Store newStore = sf.createOrGetStore("XYZ", "int32", "ustring");
System.out.println("Size of the 'XYZ' store before deserialize: " + newStore.size());
// We are going to populate this empty store by deserializing the serialized content into this new store.
try {
   newStore.deserialize(serializedStore);
   System.out.println("Successfully deserialized into the store 'XYZ'");
} catch (StoreException se) {
   System.out.println("Problem in deserializing the byte buffer into the store 'XYZ'. Error code = " +
      se.getErrorCode() + ", Error msg = " + se.getErrorMessage());
   throw se;            
}

System.out.println("Size of the 'XYZ' store after deserialize: " + newStore.size());

    • getStoreName

      String getStoreName()
      Returns:
      store name provided at store creation

    • getKeySplTypeName

      String getKeySplTypeName()
      Returns:
      the SPL type for the keys in the store

    • getValueSplTypeName

      String getValueSplTypeName()
      Returns:
      the SPL type for each value in the store

    • iterator

      StoreIterator iterator()
      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<KeyValuePair>
      Returns:
      a StoreIterator, which is an iterator over this store's contents, where each key and value is represented by a KeyValuePair. The returned iterator is a subclass of Iterator Note that this is one way to iterate over the store's contents, Iteration could also be done using a "foreach" statement.
